newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Consumer confidence up in Hong Kong - MasterCard.
newsitem.headline: Consumer confidence up in Hong Kong - MasterCard.

text.p: Consumer confidence has risen in British-run Hong Kong, which returns to Chinese rule in just 130 days, MasterCard International Inc said on Friday.

The company said its 1996 fourth quarter index on the territory showed it hit a score of 59.1, close to levels of between 60 and 64 reached in 1993 and 1994, and up from its record low of 32 in the second quarter of 1995.
"The mood in Hong Kong is very positive and this bodes well for the handover," it said in a statement.
Hong Kong residents were also very optimistic about income regularity, standing at 84.9, and the economy, at 66.7.
Average consumer confidence in China, at 69.7, was higher than in Hong Kong, with southern provinces scoring even higher.
Confidence level in Guangzhou, in southern Guangdong province, stood at 74.1, with Beijing at 62.5.
Index results were mixed for the rest of Asia.
Malaysia hit 90.4, while Thailand scored 70, up from 53 in the third quarter 1996. Indonesia emerged top scorer at 94, and the Philippines at 83.3.
In Singapore, however, the index took a tumble to 80.6 from 84.5 in the second quarter of 1996, while Japan managed only 20, down from 35 in the second quarter of 1996.
Korea nosedived to 15 from 43.7 in the last survey, while India scored 47.2, down 20 points from a year ago.
Australia stood at 57.2 and New Zealand 57.9 while Taiwan managed 48.5.
